Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: PFISR Ion-Neutral Observations in the Thermosphere (PINOT)
Award.AbstractNarration: This collaborative research effort will study magnetosphere-ionosphere-thermosphere coupling through a coordinated campaign of observations and modeling using the Poker Flat Incoherent-Scatter Radar (PFISR), the Resolute Bay Incoherent-Scatter Radar (RISR), a variety of optical instruments, the Super Dual Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN), the Homer Very High Frequency (VHF) radar, and the Global Ionospheric-Thermospheric Model (GITM). The ionosphere, thermosphere, and magnetosphere comprise a tightly coupled system at high latitudes. The ionosphere is the mediating element in this view, facilitating the transfer of free energy generated by solar wind-magnetosphere coupling into heat and bulk motion of the neutral atmosphere. This mediation occurs through electric fields, particle precipitation, diffusion, and field-aligned currents, agents that act collectively to structure the plasma density and composition within the system. Although elements of this system have been studied in considerable detail, their nonlinear interactions, and the global implications of these regional processes, remains poorly understood and inadequately observed. The electronic steering capability of PFISR offers a unique diagnostic to fill this gap. Using a dense grid of beams, a three-dimensional, time dependent view of the ion-neutral interactions can be developed. These results, in coordination with observations by common volume optical, and VHF and HF radar observations, allow access to system dynamics and system responses which were previously unobservable. The experimental campaign, involving twenty researchers from nine institutions, will be carried out over two winter seasons. The results will be used to address fundamental questions of the physics of the upper atmosphere and its coupling to the magnetosphere and the lower atmosphere, which have remained obscured for lack of key data. As a result, although it is understood that small-scale processes play critically important roles in this coupling, they have been difficult to include in quantitative models. The new information will be implemented in the GITM model validating the new understanding of the coupled magnetosphere, ionosphere and thermosphere, and thereby providing enhanced simulation capabilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The upper atmosphere of the Earth is very different than the lower atmosphere. Above about 100 km altitude, the atmosphere starts to ionize, becoming a mixture of neutral gas, ions, and electrons.  The neutral gas wants to behave like the lower atmosphere mostly, but the ions and electrons are influenced quite strongly by very different forces.  For example, electric fields force electrons and ions to move in very different ways than the neutrals. 

 

At high latitudes, the northern (and southern) lights, or aurora, cause an increase in the amount of ions and electrons in the atmosphere.  In addition, there are typically very strong electric fields associated with the aurora, which then drives the ions and electrons to move rapidly.  The presence of the fast moving ions in the slower moving background neutral atmosphere causes two things to happen: the atmosphere heats up dramatically and the winds in the neutral atmosphere change significantly.

 

Researchers investigate these types of phenomena in order to understand how the atmosphere changes due to energy inputs.  Practically, as energy is added to the atmosphere, it swells, which changes the density at low Earth orbiting satellite altitudes (such as where the International Space Station is located), which can alter their orbit.  It is critically important that these changes in orbit are understood, so we can predict when and where collisions between satellites may occur and take evasive action.

 

We do not have a very good understanding of how the energy added sometimes causes large changes in temperature and sometimes it causes small changes.  This research grant specifically was looking at time periods in which the aurora would be strong for a few hours. We tried to simulate the atmospheric response to the aurora in these events to varying levels of success.  One of the problems that we ran into was that the aurora is not very well understood or measured, so it is quite difficult to actually specify how much energy is coming into the atmosphere. Without knowing this key parameter (how much energy is entering the atmosphere), it is extremely difficult to specify what the exact response of the upper atmosphere will be. We simulated one event about 10 times using the best possible methods of specifying the energy input and we got very different results every time.  This showed us that we needed to do a much better job of measuring the aurora and the associated electric fields. We published a paper in which we detailed these issues.

 

Even though we don’t have a great ability to precisely measure the energy input, we can still conduct numerical experiments to explore what will happen in general. We conducted a series of numerical experiments to determine things like at what altitude the energy is deposited, how much uplifting the atmosphere experiences, and how the winds in the upper atmosphere are affected by the energy input. We published a study comparing our model results of generic energy input events to statistical measurements of these types of events, detailing the above effects.
